data.title: Afghanistan has launched retaliatory attacks on Pakistani border posts, Taliban military unit says
data.description:
KABUL, Feb 26 (Reuters) - Afghanistan has launched offensive operations against Pakistani military positions along the border, the Taliban's spokesperson said on Thursday, in retaliation for recent Pakistani airstrikes.

"In response to repeated provocations and violations by Pakistani military circles, large-scale offensive operations have been launched against Pakistani military positions and installations along the Durand Line," Zabihullah Mujahid, spoksperson for the Taliban administration, said in a post on X.

(Reporting by Mohammad Yunus Yawar and Sayed Hassib in Kabul; writing by Ariba Shahid; Editing by Hugh Lawson)

data.title: USITC to probe impact of revoking permanent normal trade ties China products
data.description:
WASHINGTON, Feb 26 (Reuters) - The U.S. International Trade Commission said on Thursday it would investigate the economic impact of revoking permanent normal trade relations treatment for all Chinese products over a six-year period.

(Reporting by Daphne Psaledakis and Bhargav Acharya;Editing by David Ljunggren)

data.title: Singapore's Wilmar profit rises on feed and industrial products boost
Belgium wants more nuclear power production, Engie's CFO says
Central U.S. Factory Activity Accelerates -- Kansas City Fed
data.description:
By Jessica Coacci

Manufacturing activity in the central U.S. rose in February, as most sub indexes were positive month over month except for those tracking employment.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City said Thursday that its Tenth District Manufacturing Survey's composite index rose to 5 from 0 in January. The zero-level marks the dividing point between expansion and contraction in the sector.

"Price growth cooled slightly from last month, but nearly half of firms reported changing prices more often than last year," said Cortney Cowley, assistant vice president at the Kansas City Fed.

The production and new orders indexes grew moderately, the survey said. Expectations for future activity ticked up with the composite index increasing to 15 from 7, as expectations for employment edged higher.

In addition, one third of firms reported that they will be able to pass through 0 to 20% of higher costs in the next 12 months.

Prices paid for raw materials eased slightly from last month, the Kansas City Fed added.

The manufacturing survey covers activity in the Tenth District, which includes Colorado, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Nebraska, Kansas, the northern half of New Mexico and the western third of Missouri.

Write to Jessica Coacci at jessica.coacci@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1140ET

data.title: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce Reports Earnings Results for the First Quarter Ended January 31, 2026
data.description:
Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce reported earnings results for the first quarter ended January 31, 2026. For the first quarter, the company reported net interest income was CAD 4,308 million compared to CAD 3,801 million a year ago. Net income was CAD 3,093 million compared to CAD 2,163 million a year ago.

Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 3.23 compared to CAD 2.2 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was CAD 3.21 compared to CAD 2.19 a year ago.

Walmart to Pay $100 Million to Settle FTC's Delivery Driver Pay Claims
data.description:
By Katherine Hamilton


Walmart agreed to pay $100 million to settle allegations from the Federal Trade Commission and 11 states that it deceived delivery drivers about their pay.

The FTC and states had alleged that Walmart showed drivers in its Spark Driver delivery program inflated base pay and tip amounts, and falsely claimed that 100% of customer tips would go to drivers.

Walmart's Spark service delivers goods to customers via gig workers and the Spark Driver app. Workers view the base pay and tips offered by Walmart when deciding whether to accept a delivery order job.

The FTC said Walmart didn't notify drivers that the payment for the advertised tip amount hadn't been preauthorized, so drivers wouldn't receive that amount if the customer was unable to cover the cost of the tip.

The retailer also didn't inform workers that it would reduce their base pay and tips when orders were removed from jobs including multiple deliveries, and didn't disclose all the conditions drivers had to meet to earn the incentive pay for completing certain tasks, the FTC said.


Write to Katherine Hamilton at katherine.hamilton@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1128ET

data.description:
The London Stock Exchange Group has announced plans to buy back lb3 billion of its own shares, as it reported full year results less than a month after it emerged that Elliott Investment Management had taken a stake. The company also hiked its final dividend 15.7% to 103 pence a share and set new guidance for the next two years. LSEG CEO David Schwimmer Spoke to Caroline Hepker and Stephen Carroll on Bloomberg Radio. Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News, competes with LSEG to provide financial news, data and information.

YTL Corporation Berhad Reports Earnings Results for the Second Quarter and Six Months Ended December 31, 2025
data.description:
YTL Corporation Berhad reported earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended December 31, 2025. For the second quarter, the company reported sales was MYR 7,586.62 million compared to MYR 8,058.89 million a year ago. Net income was MYR 438.03 million compared to MYR 580.01 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was MYR 0.0386 compared to MYR 0.0526 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was MYR 0.0362 compared to MYR 0.0517 a year ago.
For the six months, sales was MYR 15,228.09 million compared to MYR 15,832.83 million a year ago. Net income was MYR 784.51 million compared to MYR 913.72 million a year ago. Basic earnings per share from continuing operations was MYR 0.068 compared to MYR 0.0829 a year ago. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations was MYR 0.0636 compared to MYR 0.0815 a year ago.

data.title: Royal Bank 1Q Earnings Lifted by Personal Banking, Markets Growth -- Update
data.description:
By Robb M. Stewart


Royal Bank of Canada's earnings rose in the first quarter as the lender saw growth in its retail banking business and capital markets operations.

The bank, the country's biggest by market value and one of the largest in North America by assets, joined its peers in Canada in turning in a stronger-than-expected profit with gains across most business segments. This came despite elevated loan-loss provisions and continued economic uncertainty with trade tensions still high globally.

Royal Bank's net income rose to 5.79 billion Canadian dollars (US$4.23 billion), or C$4.03 a share, for the three months to Jan. 31, from C$5.13 billion, or C$3.54, a year earlier. Excluding certain items, adjusted per-share earnings rose to C$4.08 in the first quarter, topping the C$3.85 expected by analysts polled by FactSet.

Total revenue rose 7.3% to C$17.96 billion, while analysts were expecting C$17.5 billion. The result was buoyed by record capital markets revenue for the quarter, asset growth in its wealth management arm, and revenue growth of 9% for personal banking and roughly 4% for commercial banking.

The Toronto-based lender's return on equity, a measure of profitability closely watched by analysts, expanded by 0.8 percentage point on last year to 17.6%.

Household spending in Canada has remained relatively resilient despite an elevated unemployment rate and the hit to parts of the economy from the Trump administration's approach to trade policy and use of tariffs. Still, the housing market has softened in recent months and economists have warned of possible stresses on households as homeowners renew mortgages at higher interest rates. Business spending also has been relatively subdued, particularly in industries exposed to the shift toward protectionist trade policies by the U.S., even as equity markets in both Canada and the U.S. notched record highs.

Royal Bank in a letter to shareholders said it expects economic growth to remain positive across most advanced economies despite trade uncertainties. Canada's economy has shown signs of improvement in recent months and the jobless rate has edged lower, and the bank forecasts modest growth in the first half of the year after what was likely a flat final quarter of 2025.

The bank, like many of its peers, projects the Bank of Canada will leave its policy interest rate steady through 2026 and it isn't anticipating tariffs imposed by the U.S. on Canadian goods to rise further, though the existing trade pact between Canada, the U.S. and Mexico is up for renegotiation this year. That backdrop, executives said, is expected to mean mortgage growth in Canada is modest this year given affordability challenges, economic uncertainty, and a pullback Canadian immigration.

Royal Bank's allowance for credit losses on performing loans was steady on the prior quarter, but the allowance on performing loans was increased.

Its provision for credit losses increased C$40 million year-over-year to C$1.09 billion, and was C$83 million higher than a quarter earlier. The result was above the C$1.06 billion analysts were looking for the bank to set aside against the risk of loan losses.

Stephen Boland, an analyst at Raymond James in Toronto, said it was a solid quarter for Royal Bank that was again supported by markets-facing operations. He said there was a notable rise in gross impaired loans for the three months after trending lower in recent quarters, but said it wasn't overly concerning. Gross impaired loans as a percentage of loans and acceptances widened to 0.86% in the latest quarter, from 0.8% a quarter earlier and 0.78% in the first quarter of fiscal 2025.

The bank's shares fell in early trading, underperforming the broader market in Canada, declining 1.9% to narrow the gain over the last three months to just over 8%.

Like each of Canada's other big banks, Royal Bank sits on a strong capital position that has allowed it to continue buying back shares and a quarter earlier supported a lift in its dividend.

Royal Bank's common equity Tier 1 ratio stood at 13.7% at the end of January, up 0.5 percentage point from the same quarter last year. That remains well above the at least 11.5% of risk-weighted assets that Canada's banking regulator requires from the big lenders.


Write to Robb M. Stewart at robb.stewart@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1103ET

data.title: Google rolls out Nano Banana 2 after viral success of AI image generation tool
data.description:
Feb 26 (Reuters) - Google on Thursday unveiled a successor to its viral Nano Banana image generation model, touting faster performance as the search-engine behemoth pushes to attract more users to its AI tools.

The model, called Nano Banana 2, is being rolled out across products, including the Gemini app, AI Mode and Lens features on Search, and Flow, its AI-powered video tool, the Alphabet-owned company said.

The launch is Google's latest in a series of moves that have propelled the company to the forefront of the AI race, helping it better compete with OpenAI's ChatGPT after suffering a string of embarrassments initially. The success has fueled a 47% surge in its stock in the past six months.

Google rolled out the Nano Banana AI image editor in August, which quickly became a viral sensation, attracting 13 million first-time users to the Gemini app in just four days in September. By mid-October, it had generated more than 5 billion images.

The tech giant followed that with the release of the upgraded Nano Banana Pro in November.

Nano Banana 2 leans on Gemini's faster and cheaper models known as Flash, which allows quicker image generation and editing, Google said, adding that it also has better instruction-following capabilities and delivers sharper details.

In November, Google released its Gemini 3 AI model, whose success prompted rival OpenAI to issue an internal "code red" to push teams to accelerate development.

Gemini 3 has significantly boosted user engagement, helping the Gemini app capture more than 750 million monthly active users at the end of December.

(Reporting by Deborah Sophia in Bengaluru; Editing by Leroy Leo)

data.title: Power Corporation of Canada authorizes a Buyback Plan.
data.description: The Board of Directors of Power Corporation of Canada has authorized a buyback plan on February 26, 2026.

data.title: Ebay slashes 6% of workforce as e-commerce firm realigns operations
data.description:
Ebay said on Thursday it is cutting about 800 jobs, or roughly 6% of its full-time workforce, as the e-commerce company moves to streamline operations and align staffing with its strategic priorities.

"We are taking steps to reinvest across our business and align our structure with our strategic priorities, which will affect certain roles across our workforce," the company said.         Here are some details:

* EBay will cut about 800 jobs, or 6% of its full-timeworkforce, as part of a restructuring aimed at aligning staffingwith long-term strategic priorities. * The layoffs follow eBay's $1.2 billion acquisition ofDepop, announced last week, as the firm doubles down onsecondhand fashion and Gen Z-focused platforms. * This is the third round of layoffs since 2023. The companycut about 1,000 roles (9%) in early 2024, citing labor costsoutpacing growth, and about 500 roles (4%) in early 2023, due toa slowdown in consumer spending post pandemic.

(Reporting by Kritika Lamba; Editing by Leroy Leo)
